replies.bodyText: I do not like this Helper pattern because it is "сбирщайн" of different logics which are combined in a class and each of each logic has noting in common with the other ones. Maybe it would be great if we could extract these separate logics into different classes and check what will be result?
replies.author: enchobelezirev

timeline.body:
Instead of using Supplier, I would suggest making two different interfaces:
- BeforeHookPhaseProvider
- AfterHookPhaseProvider
These two interfaces will be implemented by each step which requires to have hooks. Each step will implement either both or one of the interfaces based on the way what is required.
timeline.bodyText:
Instead of using Supplier, I would suggest making two different interfaces:

BeforeHookPhaseProvider
AfterHookPhaseProvider
These two interfaces will be implemented by each step which requires to have hooks. Each step will implement either both or one of the interfaces based on the way what is required.
timeline.bodyHTML:
Instead of using Supplier, I would suggest making two different interfaces:

  • BeforeHookPhaseProvider
  • AfterHookPhaseProvider
    These two interfaces will be implemented by each step which requires to have hooks. Each step will implement either both or one of the interfaces based on the way what is required.
timeline.author: enchobelezirev

replies.bodyText:
Something more, it will be tricky how the SyncFlowableStepWithHooks will handle the providers. It would be better if it is doing more abstract work and somehow not be related with the step. For instance, SyncFlowableStepWithHooks should be converted to some HookProcessor(or similar) and to use the new interfaces in order to aggregate the hooks.
If we manage to do this, the StopAppStep will look like this:
StopAppStep extends TimeoutAsyncFlowableStep implements AffterHookPhaseProvider...
replies.author: enchobelezirev

replies.bodyText: As you have noticed its only one element unless there are repeating hooks. But this also covers the case that the hook will be executed only one time even though it has repeating phases. In my opinion, it's safer this way.

timeline.body:
This can be replaced with
`alreadyExecutedHooks.merge(hook.getName(), hookPhasesBasedOnCurrentHookPhase, ListUtils::union);`
This will insert the hooks list, if that hook isn't present, or, it will add them to the existing ones, otherwise

timeline.body:
This method can be done with one `stream().filter().collect()` chain. 
 hook -> !alreadyExecutedHooks.containsKey(hook.getName()) || !hasNonExecutedPhases(alreadyExecutedHooks, hook, hookPhaseForCurrentStepPhase)
That way, there is no need for the following 2 methods

timeline.body:
We can use this in the `determineModuleFromAppName` method as well, so move it above the second if condition.
Also, since that `determine` method does the same as the `findModuleByNameFromDeploymentDescriptor` method only with one more processing of the module name, we can refactor this method so as to "determine" the module name that needs checking in the if statement (whether it's directly from the cloud application object, or after mta metadata / env parsing) and then passing it to the `findModule` method.
Some renaming may be worthwhile and maybe some extracting into methods
timeline.bodyText:

timeline.bodyHTML:
I was thinking more along the lines of

Module determineModuleFromDescriptor(...){
   HandlerFactory handlerFactory = getHandlerFactory();
   String moduleName = computeModuleName(...);
   return findModuleByName(...);
}

String computeModuleName(...) {
   if (cloudApp.getModuleName() == null {
      return parseModuleName(); //use getDeployedMtaApplication().getModuleName() here
   }
   return cloudApp.getModuleName();
}

But your solution is good as well

timeline.body:
This refactoring introduces a lot of copy-pasted code. Meaning that if I want to enable the hooks in another step, I need to copy-paste this code which does all the magic. My point is that we need to make external logic which should handles this before and after step hooks calculation. Also this logic should use the newly introduced interfaces in order to operate. Meaning that when some step is started, if it is "specified" that it supports hooks, the hook building logic should understand that this step is either of type "AfterStepHookPhaseProvider" and/or "BeforeStepHookPhaseProvider" and calculate the hooks based on the current step phase.
We could discuss it - the design and the whole concept.
Try thinking of a pattern which is executing some logic by calling some delegates in order to do its job.

Meaning that when some step is started, if it is "specified" that it supports hooks, the hook building logic should understand that this step is either of type "AfterStepHookPhaseProvider" and/or "BeforeStepHookPhaseProvider" and calculate the hooks based on the current step phase.
We could discuss it - the design and the whole concept.
